items.title: Australia news live: protesters chant ‘we have the right to demonstrate’ at rally outside Sydney police station after alleged brutality at Herzog protest
items.standfirst: Follow the latest news liveSydney protest: NSW premier Chris Minns defends police in ‘impossible situation’ after video emerges of officers punching protestersGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe NSW premier, Chris Minns, is making the first of multiple appearances across the media this morning following the violent clashes between police and protesters yesterday evening.He has told Channel Nine’s Today program that police were “put in an impossible situation last night”:It’s worth remembering they did everything possible to avoid that confrontation, starting last week when they begged protest organisers to have it in Hyde Park, where it was safe and a march could take place.I know that some of the scenes on media are short clips, but people have to understand the circumstances where protesters breached police lines and ran amuck in Sydney would have been devastating.No. She’s wrong. I’m not going to throw police under the bus this morning. This is a situation that’s incredibly combustible. And the circumstances that weren’t shown on the news this morning or on TV last night because is what would have happened if protesters breached police lines ...It would have dangerous … as difficult as the scenes were to watch, it would have been infinitely worse if NSW police didn’t do their job last night.I think the - the protest organisers, when both the police and the courts said to them, yes, you can protest, but you can either do it in a stationary way here in Town Hall, if you want to march, you can march through a different part of the city, should have heeded that advice.But of course, some of the videos that we’ve seen have been very concerning. And I expect they’ll be investigated. Continue reading...
items.content: Follow the latest news liveSydney protest: NSW premier Chris Minns defends police in ‘impossible situation’ after video emerges of officers punching protestersGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe NSW premier, Chris Minns, is making the first of multiple appearances across the media this morning following the violent clashes between police and protesters yesterday evening.He has told Channel Nine’s Today program that police were “put in an impossible situation last night”:It’s worth remembering they did everything possible to avoid that confrontation, starting last week when they begged protest organisers to have it in Hyde Park, where it was safe and a march could take place.I know that some of the scenes on media are short clips, but people have to understand the circumstances where protesters breached police lines and ran amuck in Sydney would have been devastating.No. She’s wrong. I’m not going to throw police under the bus this morning. This is a situation that’s incredibly combustible. And the circumstances that weren’t shown on the news this morning or on TV last night because is what would have happened if protesters breached police lines ...It would have dangerous … as difficult as the scenes were to watch, it would have been infinitely worse if NSW police didn’t do their job last night.I think the - the protest organisers, when both the police and the courts said to them, yes, you can protest, but you can either do it in a stationary way here in Town Hall, if you want to march, you can march through a different part of the city, should have heeded that advice.But of course, some of the videos that we’ve seen have been very concerning. And I expect they’ll be investigated. Continue reading...

items.title: NSW police punch person multiple times during Sydney anti-Herzog protest – video
items.standfirst: Police cracked down on people in Sydney protesting a visit by the Israeli president, Isaac Herzog. Footage provided to Guardian Australia appears to show a person being repeatedly punched by a police officer while on the ground. The New South Wales premier, Chris Minns, has defended the actions of police at a rally against Herzog’s visit, after video footage emerged showing officers repeatedly punching a number of protestersChris Minns defends police in ‘impossible situation’ after video emerges of officers punching protesters in SydneyClashes with police as protests erupt in Sydney and Melbourne against Herzog’s visit – in pictures Continue reading...

Footage provided to Guardian Australia appears to show a person being repeatedly punched by a police officer while on the ground. The New South Wales premier, Chris Minns, has defended the actions of police at a rally against Herzog’s visit, after video footage emerged showing officers repeatedly punching a number of protestersChris Minns defends police in ‘impossible situation’ after video emerges of officers punching protesters in SydneyClashes with police as protests erupt in Sydney and Melbourne against Herzog’s visit – in pictures Continue reading...

items.title: Sussan Ley’s allies urge Angus Taylor’s backers ‘put your name to it’ amid leadership plot to oust her
items.standfirst: Push discussed in private talks and echoes tactic of then-Liberal prime minister Malcolm Turnbull used against Peter DuttonFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastSussan Ley’s allies want the Liberal leader to demand her rivals put their names to a petition calling for a spill, forcing Angus Taylor’s backers to publicly reveal themselves as plotting to oust her.The push was discussed in private talks on Tuesday and has echoes of the tactic then-Liberal prime minister Malcolm Turnbull used to stall Peter Dutton’s ultimately failed leadership coup in 2018. Continue reading...

items.title: Sheikh who led prayer at Sydney protest against Herzog says police were ‘unhinged and aggressive’
items.standfirst: Any officers who acted unlawfully should face prosecution for actions, Muslim groups sayFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastNew South Wales police who grabbed men kneeling in prayer during a protest in Sydney against Israeli president Isaac Herzog’s visit should face prosecution, a coalition of Muslim organisations has said.The joint statement demanded an apology from the state premier and called for the resignation of the NSW police commissioner after the incident on Monday night, with the man leading the prayer calling the police response “unhinged” and “aggressive”. Continue reading...

items.title: Video shows police repeatedly punching man at Sydney anti-Herzog protests – video
items.standfirst: Police cracked down on people in Sydney protesting a visit by the Israeli president, Isaac Herzog, on Monday evening. Footage provided to Guardian Australia by the Greens senator David Shoebridge shows one person being repeatedly punched by multiple police officers before being tackled to the ground. Police said 27 people were arrested and a number of protesters were treated after being pepper-sprayed. According to police, 10 officers were ‘assaulted’ but none of those assaults were seriousPolice use pepper spray at Sydney rally against Isaac Herzog visit, with MP alleging officers threw punches Continue reading...

Footage provided to Guardian Australia by the Greens senator David Shoebridge shows one person being repeatedly punched by multiple police officers before being tackled to the ground. Police said 27 people were arrested and a number of protesters were treated after being pepper-sprayed. items.title: ‘Disturbing’: Australian government demands review of Roblox’s PG rating after reports of child grooming
items.standfirst: Communications minister Anika Wells points to media reports alleging children can access spaces meant for adults which include explicit sexual contentFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastReports of child grooming and vile content on popular game service Roblox has “alarmed” the communications minister, Anika Wells, who has demanded the platform explain how it is addressing sexual and self-harm material, and that its PG rating be examined by the Australian Classification Board.The eSafety commissioner has also written to the game platform, saying it plans to test the promises it made about keeping children safe online, including disabling chat features and making underage accounts private. Continue reading...
items.content: Communications minister Anika Wells points to media reports alleging children can access spaces meant for adults which include explicit sexual contentFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastReports of child grooming and vile content on popular game service Roblox has “alarmed” the communications minister, Anika Wells, who has demanded the platform explain how it is addressing sexual and self-harm material, and that its PG rating be examined by the Australian Classification Board.The eSafety commissioner has also written to the game platform, saying it plans to test the promises it made about keeping children safe online, including disabling chat features and making underage accounts private. Continue reading...

clusters.title: DFAT 'apologises unreservedly' to families of methanol poisoning victims
clusters.neutral_headline: DFAT 'apologises unreservedly' to families of methanol poisoning victims
bullet_summary: The parents of two teens only found out the results of a trial from other victims

items.title: DFAT 'apologises unreservedly' to families of methanol poisoning victims
items.standfirst: The parents of two teens only found out the results of a trial from other victims.
items.content: The Australian government has apologised for failing to keep the families of two Australians who died in Laos from methanol poisoning updated on a court case.The People's Court of Vang Vieng in the southeast Asian country fined 10 people $185 for their roles in the deaths at Nana Backpacker Hostel in 2024, after guests were served alcohol tainted with methanol.The findings were made in secret, but the families of Holly Bowles and Bianca Jones, two 19-year-old Australians who died, only found out about the decision from other victims of the poisoning instead of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT).LIVE UPDATES: NSW Premier defends police after 'incendiary' mass protestThe department "apologised unreservedly" to the families for failing to keep the families properly informed of proceedings."The Department prides itself in its commitment to consular service and to ensuring that the interests of consular clients and their families are paramount. On this occasion, we fell short of our aspiration," a statement published this morning said.EPSTEIN FILES: Ghislaine Maxwell cites fifth Amendment as she declines to answer inquiry"Australian officials continue to underscore our expectations of a thorough and transparent investigation and that there is justice for Holly and Bianca."The fathers of Bowles and Jones had previously expressed their frustration with being kept in the dark as the court case went underway behind closed doors.ROYALS: King Charles' explosive declaration as police probe brother's Epstein links"As citizens of this country we expect the government to look after their people and get justice for their citizens when they go travelling," Mr Jones told 9news yesterday."We can't get into the country. There's nothing more we can do. We need the government to do something because we are out of options," Mr Bowles added.The accused were charged late last month for destroying evidence, with those verdicts relating to the death of a US citizen who also drank the tainted alcohol at the hostel.NEVER MISS A STORY: Get your breaking news and exclusive stories first by following us across all platforms.Download the 9NEWS App here via Apple and Google PlayMake 9News your preferred source on Google by ticking this box hereSign up to our breaking newsletter here

items.title: Man charged after police allegedly find 125,000 child abuse files
items.standfirst: A man appears in court after police officers seize a mobile and laptop with allegedly more than 125,000 files of child abuse material.
items.content: A man appears in court after police officers seize a mobile and laptop with allegedly more than 125,000 files of child abuse material.

clusters.title: Deadline looms for Warren Tredrea to pay Nine's legal costs after failed appeal against unfair dismissal case
clusters.neutral_headline: Deadline looms for Warren Tredrea to pay Nine's legal costs after...

items.title: Deadline looms for Warren Tredrea to pay Nine's legal costs after failed appeal against unfair dismissal case
items.standfirst: Former footballer Warren Tredrea has an imminent deadline to pay $149,000 to his former employer, Channel Nine, following a failed appeal against an unfair dismissal case.
items.content: Former footballer Warren Tredrea has an imminent deadline to pay $149,000 to his former employer, Channel Nine, following a failed appeal against an unfair dismissal case.

clusters.title: Chappell Roan splits with Wasserman agency amid Maxwell email controversy
clusters.neutral_headline: Chappell Roan splits with Wasserman agency amid Maxwell email controversy

items.title: Chappell Roan splits with Wasserman agency amid Maxwell email controversy
items.standfirst: Pop star Chappell Roan says she is no longer represented by the talent agency led by Los Angeles 2028 Olympics chief Casey Wasserman, who has faced criticism for flirtatious email exchanges with convicted sex trafficker Ghislaine Maxwell more than 20 years ago.
items.content: Pop star Chappell Roan says she is no longer represented by the talent agency led by Los Angeles 2028 Olympics chief Casey Wasserman, who has faced criticism for flirtatious email exchanges with convicted sex trafficker Ghislaine Maxwell more than 20 years ago.

clusters.title: Queensland MP Nigel Dalton crosses floor during vote on abortion debate
clusters.neutral_headline: Queensland MP Nigel Dalton crosses floor during vote on abortion debate

items.title: Queensland MP Nigel Dalton crosses floor during vote on abortion debate
items.standfirst: First-term Liberal National Party MP Nigel Dalton votes to overturn a ban on debating abortion — in defiance of his party.
items.content: First-term Liberal National Party MP Nigel Dalton votes to overturn a ban on debating abortion — in defiance of his party.

clusters.title: Man spared jail over 'abhorrent' social media posts threatening politicians
clusters.neutral_headline: Man spared jail over 'abhorrent' social media posts threatening politicians

items.title: Man spared jail over 'abhorrent' social media posts threatening politicians
items.standfirst: A Sydney man who made "abhorrent" social media posts that promoted sexual violence and threatened the prime minister has been spared time in custody.
items.content: A Sydney man who made "abhorrent" social media posts that promoted sexual violence and threatened the prime minister has been spared time in custody.

clusters.title: Harmful drinking water, $2.50-an-hour pay: What's happening with Carnival?
clusters.neutral_headline: Harmful drinking water, $2.50-an-hour pay: What's happening with Carnival

items.title: Harmful drinking water, $2.50-an-hour pay: What's happening with Carnival?
items.standfirst: A major cruise ship has been investigated by the maritime safety regulator for claims around poor working conditions. A spokesperson for The Carnival Cruise Line says it has "nothing to hide" and welcomes AMSA's oversight.
items.content: A major cruise ship has been investigated by the maritime safety regulator for claims around poor working conditions. A spokesperson for The Carnival Cruise Line says it has "nothing to hide" and welcomes AMSA's oversight.

clusters.title: Mental health clinicians to flag 'high-risk' patients in gun licence crackdown
clusters.neutral_headline: Mental health clinicians to flag 'high-risk' patients in gun licence crackdown

items.title: Mental health clinicians to flag 'high-risk' patients in gun licence crackdown
items.standfirst: A raft of new gun laws in response to the Wieambilla shooting falls short of mandatory mental health checks for gun licence applicants.
items.content: A raft of new gun laws in response to the Wieambilla shooting falls short of mandatory mental health checks for gun licence applicants.

clusters.title: Bondi terrorist father was 'more extremist' than son, former spy says
clusters.neutral_headline: Bondi terrorist father was 'more extremist' than son, former spy says

items.title: Bondi terrorist father was 'more extremist' than son, former spy says
items.standfirst: Bondi Beach terrorist Sajid Akram voiced support for the Islamic State group (IS) in 2019 and expressed admiration for a leading Al Qaeda propagandist, according to accounts from two men who moved in the same extremist circles.
items.content: Bondi Beach terrorist Sajid Akram voiced support for the Islamic State group (IS) in 2019 and expressed admiration for a leading Al Qaeda propagandist, according to accounts from two men who moved in the same extremist circles.
